# First 5 California Programs Overview

## What is First 5?
State commission funded by tobacco tax (Proposition 10) to improve early childhood development.

## Programs and Services

### Children and Families Commissions
- 58 county commissions
- Local funding decisions
- Community-based programs

### Common Investments
- Quality childcare improvement
- Family support services
- Health and developmental screenings
- Parent education

## First 5 and Childcare

### Quality Improvement
- QRIS implementation funding
- Provider training grants
- Facility improvements

### Access Expansion
- Childcare slots funding
- Start-up grants for providers
- Infrastructure support

### Family Support
- Parent education programs
- Family Resource Centers
- Home visiting programs

## Finding First 5 Services
- **First5.ca.gov**: State website
- **County First 5**: Search by county
- **R&R agencies**: Know local programs

## Free Services Often Available
- Developmental screenings
- Parent workshops
- Support groups
- Resource navigation

## Connect with First 5
- No income requirements for many programs
- Available to all families with young children
- Great complement to childcare

# Dental and Vision Care for Young Children

## Early Dental Care

### CHDP (Child Health and Disability Prevention)
- Free dental assessments
- Required for childcare/school
- Referrals for treatment

### Medi-Cal Dental (Denti-Cal)
- Covers children in Medi-Cal
- Preventive care
- Treatment as needed

### Head Start Dental
- Screenings included
- Treatment coordination
- Oral health education

## Vision Screening

### Required Screenings
- Before kindergarten entry
- Through CHDP or provider
- Early detection important

### Vision Services
- Medi-Cal covers exams
- Glasses covered if needed
- Follow-up care available

## Childcare Provider Role

### Health Requirements
- Up-to-date health assessment
- Vision/hearing screening
- Dental assessment

### Referral Help
- Providers can share resources
- Head Start coordinates services
- R&R can provide referrals

## Finding Services
- County CHDP office
- Medi-Cal provider lists
- Community health centers
- First 5 programs

# Developmental Screening and Early Intervention

## Why Screening Matters
Early identification of delays leads to better outcomes.

## Screening Opportunities

### Childcare Settings
- Licensed programs may screen
- QRIS programs likely to screen
- Ages and Stages Questionnaire common

### Head Start
- Required screening within 45 days
- Multiple domains assessed
- Referrals provided

### Well-Child Visits
- Pediatricians screen at visits
- Developmental milestones checked
- Autism screening at 18, 24 months

## Early Intervention Programs

### Early Start (Birth to 3)
- California's early intervention program
- Free assessment
- Services if eligible
- Regional Center coordinates

### Special Education Preschool (3-5)
- School district responsibility
- Free evaluation
- IEP if eligible
- Services in least restrictive environment

## What Gets Screened
- Motor development
- Language/communication
- Cognitive development
- Social-emotional
- Adaptive/self-help

## If Concerns Identified
1. Referral for evaluation
2. Comprehensive assessment
3. Eligibility determination
4. Services if eligible
5. Regular progress monitoring

## Parent Rights
- Request evaluation anytime
- Participate in planning
- Receive services in native language
- Appeal decisions

# Positive Discipline in Childcare Settings

## California Requirements

### Prohibited Practices
- Corporal punishment (spanking, hitting)
- Withholding food as punishment
- Isolation/confinement
- Verbal abuse
- Shaming

### Required Approach
- Positive guidance
- Developmentally appropriate
- Consistent and fair
- Documented policy

## Positive Discipline Techniques

### Prevention
- Clear, simple rules
- Consistent routines
- Age-appropriate expectations
- Environmental design

### Redirection
- Offer alternatives
- Change activity
- Move to new area

### Natural Consequences
- Related to behavior
- Reasonable
- Respectful

### Positive Reinforcement
- Notice good behavior
- Encourage effort
- Specific praise

## What Parents Should Expect

### Ask About
- Discipline policy (should be written)
- How challenging behavior handled
- Communication with parents
- Time-out policies

### Red Flags
- Harsh language to children
- Children afraid
- Injuries from discipline
- Secrecy about methods

## If Concerned About Discipline
1. Talk to provider
2. Review written policy
3. Contact licensing if needed
4. Consider changing providers

# Screen Time Policies in Childcare

## Licensing Regulations

### What's Restricted
- Television watching limited
- Video games restricted
- Computer use guidelines
- Applies to licensed care

### Allowed Uses
- Educational programming
- Short duration
- Interactive technology for learning
- Teacher-directed activities

## Best Practices

### Ages 0-2
- No screen time recommended (except video chat)
- Focus on interaction and play

### Ages 2-5
- Limited quality programming
- Co-viewing encouraged
- Not during meals
- Not before nap/bed

## Questions to Ask Providers

- What is your screen time policy?
- How much daily screen time?
- What type of programming?
- How is it supervised?
- Can I opt my child out?

## Signs of Good Practice
- Written policy available
- Minimal screen use
- Active play prioritized
- Screens not used for behavior management
- Educational when used

## Your Rights
- Request no screen time
- Know what children watch
- Discuss concerns with provider

## At Home Consistency
- Consider matching policies
- AAP recommendations
- Quality matters more than quantity

# Sleep and Rest in Childcare Settings

## Safe Sleep for Infants

### Licensing Requirements
- Back to sleep position
- Firm, flat surface
- No soft bedding
- Individual cribs/bassinets
- No blankets, pillows, toys

### Provider Training
- Safe sleep training required
- SIDS awareness
- Swaddling guidelines

## Toddler Nap Time

### Typical Schedule
- One nap, early afternoon
- 1-3 hours depending on age
- Quiet rest time

### Sleeping Arrangements
- Cots or mats typically
- Individual bedding
- Supervision required

## Preschool Rest Time

### Requirements
- Opportunity to rest
- Quiet activities if not sleeping
- Reasonable duration

### Children Who Don't Nap
- Quiet activities available
- Can read or play quietly
- Cannot be forced to sleep

## Questions for Providers

- What is the nap/rest schedule?
- Where do children sleep?
- What if my child doesn't nap?
- Safe sleep practices for infants?
- How long is rest time?

## Coordinating Home/Care Sleep

- Share sleep schedule
- Discuss sleep challenges
- Consistency helps
- Transition items (blanket, stuffed animal)

## If Concerned About Sleep Practices
- Discuss with provider
- Check licensing requirements
- Report safety concerns to licensing

# Outdoor Play Requirements in Childcare

## Licensing Requirements

### Centers
- Outdoor space required
- 75 square feet per child (outdoor)
- Daily outdoor time expected
- Safe, fenced area

### Family Childcare
- Outdoor play required
- Fenced or supervised
- Age-appropriate equipment

## Benefits of Outdoor Play

### Physical Development
- Gross motor skills
- Coordination
- Physical fitness
- Healthy habits

### Cognitive Benefits
- Exploration and discovery
- Problem solving
- Creativity
- Science learning

### Social-Emotional
- Cooperative play
- Risk assessment
- Confidence building

## Weather Considerations

### Hot Weather
- Shade required
- Hydration
- Modified activity levels
- Sunscreen policies

### Cold/Rainy Weather
- May modify outdoor time
- Indoor gross motor alternatives
- Appropriate clothing

## Questions for Providers

- How much daily outdoor time?
- What equipment is available?
- Shade and water access?
- Supervision during outdoor play?
- Weather modification policies?

## Safety Standards
- Equipment inspection
- Fall surfaces
- Supervision ratios maintained
- First aid accessible

# Childcare Emergency Preparedness

## Required Plans

### Emergency Plans
Licensed providers must have:
- Emergency contact information
- Evacuation procedures
- Shelter-in-place procedures
- Reunification plans
- Communication procedures

### Drills
- Fire drills (monthly)
- Earthquake drills
- Lockdown practice
- Documentation required

## Types of Emergencies

### Natural Disasters
- Earthquakes
- Wildfires
- Floods
- Severe weather

### Other Emergencies
- Medical emergencies
- Facility emergencies
- Community threats
- Utility outages

## Parent Responsibilities

### Provide
- Emergency contact numbers
- Authorized pickup people
- Medical information
- Special needs information

### Know
- Evacuation meeting points
- Communication plan
- Pickup procedures
- Alternate contacts

## Questions to Ask

- What is emergency plan?
- How will I be contacted?
- Where is evacuation location?
- How do I pick up during emergency?
- Are staff trained?

## After Emergencies

### Childcare may be disrupted
- Emergency childcare resources
- Contact R&R for assistance
- Family and friend network
- Employer understanding

# Communication Between Parents and Providers

## Daily Communication

### Infants/Toddlers
- Daily sheets common
- Feeding times and amounts
- Diaper changes
- Sleep/nap times
- Activities
- Mood/behavior notes

### Preschool/School-Age
- Less detailed daily reports
- Notable events shared
- Artwork sent home
- Weekly newsletters

## Communication Methods

### In-Person
- Drop-off conversations
- Pick-up discussions
- Scheduled conferences

### Written
- Daily sheets
- Notes in cubbies
- Newsletters
- Calendars

### Digital
- Parent apps (Brightwheel, HiMama)
- Email
- Text (if appropriate)
- Photo sharing

## Parent-Teacher Conferences

### Typical Schedule
- 2x per year minimum
- More if needed
- Document child progress
- Set goals together

## Sharing Concerns

### If You Have Concerns
1. Schedule private conversation
2. Be specific about concerns
3. Ask questions
4. Listen to perspective
5. Work on solutions together

### When Provider Has Concerns
- Take seriously
- Ask for specifics
- Discuss strategies
- Follow up

## Building Partnership
- Share relevant home information
- Acknowledge provider's expertise
- Respect boundaries
- Express appreciation

# Transitioning to Kindergarten

## Kindergarten Readiness

### What Schools Expect
- Social-emotional skills
- Self-help skills (bathroom, eating)
- Following directions
- Basic communication
- Interest in learning

### What's NOT Required
- Reading
- Writing name
- Counting to 100
- Sitting still for hours

## Preschool's Role

### Transition Support
- Kindergarten readiness curriculum
- School visits
- Transition meetings
- Skills development

### Documentation
- Progress reports
- Assessment results
- Portfolio of work
- Teacher observations

## Timeline

### Year Before Kindergarten
- Research school options
- Visit schools
- Check registration dates
- Apply to schools of choice

### Spring Before Kindergarten
- Register (usually March-May)
- Attend orientation
- Meet teacher if possible

### Summer Before
- Practice routines
- Visit school/playground
- Positive discussions about school

## Children with IEPs

### Transition Planning
- Transition meeting required
- IEP transfers to school district
- Services continue
- Parent participation important

## Helping Children Adjust
- Talk positively about kindergarten
- Read books about starting school
- Practice independence skills
- Establish school-ready routines

# Home Visiting Programs

## What is Home Visiting?
Voluntary programs where trained professionals visit families at home to support child development and family well-being.

## Common Programs in California

### Nurse-Family Partnership
- First-time, low-income mothers
- Nurse visitors
- Pregnancy through age 2

### Parents as Teachers
- Birth through kindergarten
- Parent educators
- Developmental screenings

### Early Head Start Home-Based
- Part of Head Start
- Birth to age 3
- Weekly visits
- Comprehensive services

### CalWORKs Home Visiting
- For CalWORKs families
- Voluntary participation
- Support services

## Benefits

### For Children
- Developmental support
- School readiness
- Health screenings
- Early intervention referrals

### For Parents
- Parenting support
- Goal setting
- Resource connections
- Confidence building

## How to Access

- First 5 county office
- R&R agency referrals
- Health department
- CalWORKs office
- Pediatrician referral

## Connection to Childcare

- Help finding childcare
- Understanding subsidies
- School readiness support
- Transition planning

# Family Resource Centers (FRCs)

## What are FRCs?
Community-based centers providing support services to families with young children.

## Common Services

### Parent Education
- Parenting classes
- Support groups
- One-on-one coaching
- Special topic workshops

### Resource Navigation
- Childcare referrals
- Subsidy information
- Community resources
- Benefits enrollment help

### Family Support
- Case management
- Crisis intervention
- Basic needs assistance
- Mental health referrals

### Child Development
- Playgroups
- Developmental screenings
- Parent-child activities
- School readiness programs

## Who Can Use FRCs?

- Open to all families (usually)
- No income requirements for most services
- Focus on families with children 0-5
- May have specialized programs

## Finding an FRC

- First 5 county website
- R&R agency referrals
- 211
- School districts
- Community centers

## FRCs and Childcare

### Help With
- Understanding childcare options
- Subsidy applications
- Choosing quality care
- Transition support

### Onsite Childcare
- Some FRCs offer care during programs
- Drop-in care during workshops
- Playgroups with supervision
